body_html:
@adamcavendish Yes, increment on variable_scope is intentional: it sees function two_batchnorm as an unit, and we create two ones here: two_batchnorm, and two_batchnorm_1.

I'm afraid that #15270 might also break the reuse behavior of tf.layers:
tf.layers.batch_normalization

reuse: Boolean, whether to reuse the weights of a previous layer by the same name.

cc @fchollet who I know might care the issue.

body:
@adamcavendish Yes, increment on variable_scope is intentional: it sees function `two_batchnorm` as an unit, and we create two ones here: `two_batchnorm`, and `two_batchnorm_1`.

I'm afraid that #15270 might also break the `reuse` behavior of `tf.layers`:
[ tf.layers.batch_normalization ](https://www.tensorflow.org/versions/master/api_docs/python/tf/layers/batch_normalization)
> reuse: Boolean, whether to reuse the weights of a previous layer by the same name.

cc @fchollet who I know might care the issue.
